title: 105_s401
content: The text introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding a tax on outdoor advertising. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 imposes a 15% tax on gross income from leasing taxable outdoor advertising displays. A taxable display is defined as any outdoor advertising display with more than 32 square feet of advertising space. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of enactment of this Act. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 establishes the Outdoor Advertising Program Trust Fund. The Outdoor Advertising Program Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by revenues from a specific tax. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer necessary amounts to the Secretary of Transportation for implementing section 131 of title 23, United States Code. Sec. 9512 establishes the Outdoor Advertising Program Trust Fund. SEC. 3 controls outdoor advertising. Section 131 of title 23, United States Code is amended to restrict the erection of new signs, displays, or devices in industrial and commercial areas. No new signs can be erected after the enactment of this amendment, with exceptions for just compensation requirements. The amendment to Section 131 of title 23, United States Code restricts the erection of new signs, displays, or devices in industrial and commercial areas. Just compensation is not required for the removal of signs erected after the enactment date, except under certain state provisions. The amendment to Section 131 of title 23, United States Code limits the total number of signs, displays, and devices in each State to those lawfully erected before the enactment date. Additionally, signs not permitted under subsection (c) can be removed under this section without the need for just compensation. The amendment to Section 131 of title 23, United States Code includes provisions for the appropriation of funds from the Outdoor Advertising Program Trust Fund for the implementation of the section. Subsection (t) now requires states to maintain an inventory of outdoor advertising signs, displays, and devices for effective control. The amendment to Section 131 of title 23, United States Code now requires states to maintain an inventory of outdoor advertising signs, displays, and devices for effective control, including identifying illegal, nonconforming, or conforming signs along scenic byways. The Secretary will use these inventories to ensure compliance. The amendment to Section 131 of title 23, United States Code requires states to maintain an inventory of outdoor advertising signs for effective control. States must not remove vegetation in right-of-ways to improve sign visibility.
